liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North Korea's state media agency KCNA has reported Kim Jong Un invited Russian President Vladimir Putin to visit North Korea during their meeting in Russia, which Putin has accepted. KCNA reports Kim has expressed a willingness to foster stable, future-oriented ties with Russia for the next 100 years.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Putin invited to visit North Korea following meeting with Kim

featuredLink.title: North Korea's leader vows full support for Russia's 'just fight' after viewing launchpads with Putin

props.alt: Russia's President Vladimir Putin and North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un

children.content: (Reuters: Sputnik/Artem Geodakyan/Pool)
North Korea's state media agency KCNA has reported Kim Jong Un invited Russian President Vladimir Putin to visit North Korea during their meeting in Russia, which Putin has accepted.
KCNA reports Kim has expressed a willingness to foster stable, future-oriented ties with Russia for the next 100 years.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: AFL legend Michael Long has completed a 650-kilometre walk from Melbourne to Canberra in support of the Yes vote in the Voice referendum, repeating his historic 2004 journey made to raise the voices of Indigenous communities. He joined Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in the prime minister's courtyard this morning. Mr Albanese said sharing the continent with "the oldest continuous culture on Earth should be and is a great source of national pride." "In 1927, Jimmy Clements, a Wurundjeri man like our Indigenous affairs minister, walked to Tumut to join with the Duke of York for the opening of parliament here in Canberra, just down the hill. "He was joined by another Indigenous man, John Noble, the only two Indigenous people at the opening of the parliament. Police tried to remove Clements because he arrived after such a long walk from Tumut, dishevelled and bare foot. "The crowd rose up and said 'No, Indigenous people have a right to be here.' "What do they teach us? Like Michael Long, they were prepared to walk a long way to meet us. "Our journey since 1788 is just a fraction of the journey that Indigenous Australians have had for 65,000 years."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AFL legend Michael Long completes two week walk for Yes vote

children.content: (ABC News)

AFL legend Michael Long has completed a 650-kilometre walk from Melbourne to Canberra in support of the Yes vote in the Voice referendum, repeating his historic 2004 journey made to raise the voices of Indigenous communities.
He joined Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in the prime minister's courtyard this morning.
Mr Albanese said sharing the continent with "the oldest continuous culture on Earth should be and is a great source of national pride."
"In 1927, Jimmy Clements, a Wurundjeri man like our Indigenous affairs minister, walked to Tumut to join with the Duke of York for the opening of parliament here in Canberra, just down the hill.

"He was joined by another Indigenous man, John Noble, the only two Indigenous people at the opening of the parliament. Police tried to remove Clements because he arrived after such a long walk from Tumut, dishevelled and bare foot.
"The crowd rose up and said 'No, Indigenous people have a right to be here.'
"What do they teach us?
Like Michael Long, they were prepared to walk a long way to meet us.
"Our journey since 1788 is just a fraction of the journey that Indigenous Australians have had for 65,000 years."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two young people living with an eating disorder are this morning going to sit across from representatives at Meta to tell the company — which owns Facebook and Instagram — about the negative effects that social media is having on them and their peers. Independent MP Zoe Daniel, who will be at the round table, told News Breakfast social media was a real driver of eating disorders which often compounded the disorder, especially on Tik Tok. "If you are diagnosed with an eating disorder, you're almost 4,000 per cent more likely to receive the next video which is eating disorder-related, and almost 400 per cent more likely that the next video you receive will be diet-related," she told the program. She said the round table will talk about the potential for things like shields that can protect people on social media platforms who have eating disorders. If you or someone you know is struggling with an eating disorder you can contact the Butterfly Foundation on 1800 33 4673.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Social media 'a driver' of eating disorders

featuredLink.title: Eating-disorder patients to confront Meta bosses as research links TikTok to harmful videos

props.alt: A woman in glasses and a red jacket.

children.content: (ABC News)

Two young people living with an eating disorder are this morning going to sit across from representatives at Meta to tell the company — which owns Facebook and Instagram — about the negative effects that social media is having on them and their peers.
Independent MP Zoe Daniel, who will be at the round table, told News Breakfast social media was a real driver of eating disorders which often compounded the disorder, especially on Tik Tok.

"If you are diagnosed with an eating disorder, you're almost 4,000 per cent more likely to receive the next video which is eating disorder-related, and almost 400 per cent more likely that the next video you receive will be diet-related," she told the program.
She said the round table will talk about the potential for things like shields that can protect people on social media platforms who have eating disorders.
If you or someone you know is struggling with an eating disorder you can contact the Butterfly Foundation on 1800 33 4673.

title.children: Wall St mixed after inflation data, ASX set to open lower, August jobs data to come

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello there, Emily Stewart here to help you navigate all today's business and finance news. The local share market is set to open lower this morning after mixed results on Wall Street overnight. US inflation figures show prices have risen to a 14-month high (mainly due to rising energy prices), however underlying inflation is actually heading lower (although very slowly). This means there could be a case for a rate pause at next week's Federal Reserve meeting. Back at home, we'll be keenly watching for the ABS jobs data which will come out at about 11:30am AEST. Stay with us!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Good morning!

children.content: Hello there,
Emily Stewart here to help you navigate all today's business and finance news.
The local share market is set to open lower this morning after mixed results on Wall Street overnight.
US inflation figures show prices have risen to a 14-month high (mainly due to rising energy prices), however underlying inflation is actually heading lower (although very slowly).
This means there could be a case for a rate pause at next week's Federal Reserve meeting.
Back at home, we'll be keenly watching for the ABS jobs data which will come out at about 11:30am AEST.
Stay with us!
